Problem:
Consider the function \\( g(z) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{st} z(t) dt \\), where \\( s \\) is a complex number and \\( z(t) \\) is a complex-valued function of time. We investigate the causal effects of operations on \\( z(t) \\) and their expression through the transformation \\( g(z) \\).

If a transformation \\( h(z) = z(t) + ce^{-dt} \\) (where c and d are constants) is applied to \\( z(t) \\) at t = 0, will \\( g(z) \\) at a later time T reflect the addition of \\( ce^{-dt} \\) exactly?
Explanation: The transformation modifies \\( z(t) \\) by adding a decaying exponential, altering the original function. The integral transformation \\( g(z) \\), being a Laplace transform, will reflect this addition, but the result won't be just an addition of constants but will involve integration of the exponential modified by \\( s \\) and \\( d \\).
